message.content:
We need to “roll‐up” (aggregate) the cost side of your revenue-producing transactions. In your (new) table every row of type “Sale” carries a number in its “cost_amount” field (which normally represents the cost of the goods sold for that transaction). To get the final “total cost” item to report in the income statement we must add all those cost_amount values.

Below is what was done step‐by‐step:

1. We inspected every “Sale” row (rows with type “Sale”). For instance, one Sale row shows
  • Sale20240102001 – cost_amount = 25000.0  
  • Sale20240102002 – cost_amount = 25000.0  
  • Sale20240103004 – cost_amount = 2880.0  
  • Sale20240103005 – cost_amount = 2640.0  
  • Sale20240104007 – cost_amount = 4400.0  
  • … and so on through all Sale rows.

2. We then summed up the 63 “Sale” transactions’ cost_amount values. (I went through all 63 sales by “hand‐calculation”.)

The sums from each sale were as follows (in order of appearance):

  25000.0 + 25000.0 + 2880.0 + 2640.0 + 4400.0 + 600.0 + 8640.0 + 14400.0 + 6000.0 + 6000.0 + 
  2000.0 + 14400.0 + 300.0 + 4400.0 + 25000.0 + 10000.0 + 5000.0 + 5760.0 + 2880.0 + 2640.0 + 
  2880.0 + 600.0 + 5000.0 + 750.0 + 2880.0 + 1050.0 + 1760.0 + 1400.0 + 1050.0 + 350.0 + 
  25000.0 + 15000.0 + 4000.0 + 11520.0 + 880.0 + 450.0 + 11520.0 + 3520.0 + 15000.0 + 6000.0 + 
  1400.0 + 11520.0 + 6000.0 + 15000.0 + 8000.0 + 6000.0 + 700.0 + 2000.0 + 15000.0 + 350.0 + 
  3520.0 + 10000.0 + 6000.0 + 1500.0 + 7500.0 + 25000.0 + 5000.0 + 7500.0 + 3000.0 + 4500.0 + 
  3000.0 + 700.0 + 2000.0

Adding these up gives 422740.0

Thus the final total cost item in the income statement is 422740.00.

Below is the answer in the requested JSON format:

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Total Cost": "422740.00"} }
```
